title: Lesson 6: Lysosomes, Peroxisomes and Cellular Digestion
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding lysosomes and peroxisomes as membrane-bound organelles responsible for cellular digestion. Students learn about autophagy, heterophagy, and the clinical significance of lysosomal storage diseases.
learningIntentions: Students can describe the structure and function of lysosomes (membrane-bound sac containing digestive enzymes).
Students can distinguish between autophagy (digesting own material) and heterophagy/phagocytosis (digesting foreign material).
Students can explain why lysosomes have an acidic interior and how this protects the cell.

syllabusLinks.module: Module 1: Cells as the Basis of Life
syllabusLinks.inquiryQuestion: IQ1: What distinguishes one cell from another?

successCriteria: I can label a lysosome and list three types of molecules it digests.
I can explain what happens when a lysosome fuses with a food vacuole or a damaged mitochondrion.
I can predict what would happen if lysosomal enzymes leaked into the cytoplasm.

prerequisites.description: Endomembrane system, Golgi apparatus, vesicle transport

engagementHook.title: The Recycling Centre
engagementHook.content: Show an image of a child with Tay-Sachs disease (developmental delay, neurodegeneration). Explain: 'This child lacks one specific enzyme in their lysosomes. Without it, cellular 'trash' piles up in the brain. Lysosomes are the cell's recycling centres—when they fail, the cell fills with waste and dies. Today we explore how these 'suicide sacs' are actually essential for life.'

keyConcepts.definition: Membrane-bound organelles containing hydrolytic enzymes (acid hydrolases) that break down carbohydrates, lipids, proteins, and nucleic acids. Formed by budding from the Golgi apparatus.
Lysosomes maintain pH ~4.5–5.0 (more acidic than cytoplasm). This acidity activates the enzymes and keeps them contained—if leaked, they are less active at neutral pH.
Lysosomes digest worn-out organelles or cell components (recycling).
Lysosomes fuse with vesicles containing food or bacteria (digestion).
Genetic disorder where a lysosomal enzyme is missing, causing fatty substances to accumulate in brain cells—demonstrates importance of lysosomal function.

misconceptions.misconception: Lysosomes digest the cell from the inside out randomly
misconceptions.correction: Emphasise they are membrane-bound and only fuse with specific targets (vacuoles or damaged organelles) under control.

misconceptions.misconception: Lysosomes are found only in animal cells
misconceptions.correction: Plant cells have lysosome-like vacuoles with digestive functions, though typical lysosomes are animal cell features.
Lysosomes contain enzymes made by the rough ER and packaged by the Golgi (link to Lesson 5).

contentSections.title: Lysosome Formation and Structure
contentSections.content: Golgi apparatus budding off vesicle → primary lysosome → fusing with food vacuole/phagosome → digestion. Shows single membrane enclosing enzymes.
contentSections.example: White blood cell engulfing bacterium—lysosome fuses with phagosome to destroy invader.
contentSections.checkForUnderstanding: Why must lysosomal enzymes be enclosed by a membrane? (To protect cytoplasm from digestion.)

contentSections.title: Autophagy vs Heterophagy
contentSections.example: Autophagy during starvation (recycling proteins for energy); heterophagy in amoeba feeding or immune response.

contentSections.title: Lysosomal Storage Diseases
contentSections.content: Tay-Sachs (missing enzyme hexosaminidase A → GM2 ganglioside accumulates in brain neurons). Pompe disease (glycogen accumulates in muscles). Shows genetic basis of organelle function.
contentSections.example: Enzyme replacement therapy for some lysosomal diseases (intravenous enzymes taken up by cells).

shortAnswer.question: Explain why the membrane surrounding a lysosome is essential for the survival of the cell. (2 marks)

definitions: Lysosomes are membrane-bound sacs containing digestive enzymes (acid hydrolases).
They bud from the Golgi apparatus.
They have an acidic interior (pH ~5) to activate enzymes.
Autophagy = digesting own material; Heterophagy = digesting foreign material.
Lysosomal storage diseases (e.g., Tay-Sachs) occur when enzymes are missing.
keyPoints: Lysosomes contain hydrolytic enzymes for breaking down macromolecules
Acidic pH (~4.5-5.0) activates enzymes and protects cytoplasm
Membrane keeps enzymes contained - leakage would digest the cell
Tay-Sachs: missing hexosaminidase A → brain damage
diagrams: Lysosome formation: Golgi → primary lysosome → fusion

shortAnswer: Lysosomes are membrane-bound organelles that contain hydrolytic (acid hydrolase) enzymes capable of breaking down macromolecules including proteins, lipids, carbohydrates and nucleic acids. They fuse with vacuoles containing foreign material (heterophagy) or with vesicles containing damaged organelles (autophagy) to digest the contents into smaller molecules that can be recycled by the cell.

The membrane surrounding a lysosome is essential because it isolates the digestive enzymes from the cytoplasm, preventing the cell from digesting itself. The membrane maintains an acidic interior (pH ~4.5-5.0) which activates the enzymes. If the membrane were breached and enzymes leaked into the cytoplasm (which has neutral pH), they would be less active but could still cause significant damage to cellular components.
